article.title: HitFraud: A Broad Learning Approach for Collective Fraud Detection in Heterogeneous Information Networks

choices: The architecture of a fraud detection system.
A simplified example of a heterogeneous information network for fraud detection.
The data flow diagram of payment transactions on an e-commerce platform.
A comparison of different payment methods and their associated risks.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the network schema in Figure 2 represent?
choices: The structure of a relational database for storing payment transaction data.
The communication protocols used in an online payment system.
The relationships between different entities in EA payment transaction data.
The different types of fraudulent behaviors observed in the dataset.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of Formula (1)?
choices: To calculate the probability of a transaction being fraudulent.
To determine the shortest path between two transactions in a heterogeneous information network.
To compute a feature representing the ratio of fraudulent transactions linked to a specific transaction through a meta-path.
To update the weights of a classifier based on the predicted labels of test transactions.
The definition of recall in the context of fraud detection.
The formula for calculating the F1-score of a classifier.
The relative improvement of HITFRAUD's performance on a specific metric compared to the baseline.
The formula for updating the predicted labels of test transactions in each iteration of HITFRAUD.
